reviewText:
I been playing this game for a while and I can tell you now that this game has gone down hill at quite the steep drop. It used to be good with a nice balance of certain weapons and such. But now?...

1. There is literally toxic clans everywhere, their quite a few I won't name but are obviously quite toxic that literally I have seen just decide to hack when they start losing. I seen passing through walls, shooting through walls, teleporting, auto kills, and ofcourse aimbots everywhere. Then when you call them out on them they just start hacking some more. The community is horrible.

2. Well from what you saw above there is a ridiculous amount of hacking that goes on in this game especially the more you play the easier it is to see. I have seen subtle hacks to full blown hacks where you just die if you look at your enemy. And Ubisoft does absolutely nothing about it.

3. The GUNS which is an important part of any shooting game...They are unbalanced like hell. Lets take for example the new pay to win AA-12. A AUTOMATIC shotgun that shoots right after each shot with 20 rounds of ammon. It can one shot you at close range and at a distance it covers a ridiculous amount of the area when shot and have high damage no matter how far you are. Then they tell you this is fair? Not even close, this gun is ridiculous and stupid.

4. What can I say? its PAY TO WIN! Literally if you don't pay, to get a good gun it will take forever as the prices of guns or armor you have to play for weeks to save up for just one thing or...You can pay 20 dollars and geta  gun that can just kill anybody  as long as you point it in the general direction of your enemy. So yeah, pay to win.

There are a few things  that are bad but those would be the main things as I don't recommend this game at all. Not in its current state. Maybe a year or two ago? Yeah I would but not now.

NOTE: I have already gotten quite the few people calling me a noob for this comment even do I been playing this game longer than they have. But what can you do when you tell people the truth.

reviewText:
A ton of fun, LOTS of teamwork, even the kids are on their mics trying to synchronize attacks and identifying targets.

They have a great idea here, which is a beginners-only mode.  Up until level 5, you can play with other people who haven't spent any money on the game.  After level 5, beginners-only is locked out.

You have 3 classes to choose from - Assault rifle, LMG/shotgun, and sniper/SMG.  While you can change weapons pertaining to your class in-game (IE if you are a sniper, you can change sniper rifles during a match), you can ONLY change classes while not in a match.

If you do not spend any real money on this game, you will be able to afford one gun after a few hours, and another gun after several days, and that's about it.  Two guns.  So make sure you pick the right ones!

This game really encourages team work.  EVERYONE uses mics, and even the ones that don't are furiously typing in the chat.  Team mates will wait until everyone has met at a certain point before advancing ahead.  They will identify enemy positions, let you know of alternate routes (there are a lot), suppress fire for you while you run ahead.  I have never seen such epic teamwork in a free-to-play game.  Even the young kids are working together!

A lot of people are saying that once you leave beginners-only mode, the game hits a huge pay-wall and becomes impossible for anyone who didn't spend money.  I did not find that to be true.  I haven't spend a dime on this game, I'm only using the basic guns, and I still find matches to be a blast.  The fact is, even if the other guys spent $30 on guns with high damage, low recoil, and extra armor, I can still kill them in one shot with a headshot, or sneak around behind their team and kill 3 of their guys with my basic LMG.  Sure, when I was playing beginners-only, I was getting in the top 3 of the scoreboard every match, and now im near the middle, but it's still fun.

So if you spend a lot of money on armor, it might mean that it takes 6 shots to kill you instead of 4 or 5.  Or if you spend it all on a nice gun, it might mean you can kill a guy in 3-4 shots instead of 5 or 6.  Or it might mean you can recover from sprinting faster, or your gun has slightly less recoil.  In the big scheme of things, spending $30 on this game will net you an extra one or two kills.  It's a slight edge, but it's not enough to ruin the game for us freeloaders.

I suggest anyone who has had a hard time after reaching level 5 to try again, it's really not that bad.

reviewText:
Pros:- Good Graphics, not the best but are suitable for the games style.
- Lots of weapons to choose from.
- They have 3 different classes, Assault, Recon and Support. All of which have their own guns and abilities.
- On classes there are abilities, these abilities are very well made and can help you your team.
- Lots of different maps.
-Very nice Cover system, you will gain accuracy and things whenever you use cover.
- 3rd Person View.



Cons:- Pay To Win, this game will always be asking you if you want to buy currency or guns.
- Unbalanced, people that have invested Real Money into the game will always have better weapons than you.
- No Match-Making System, this game has no Match-Making System after you finish your beginner games. You will always be matched with people that are better than you and people that have Premium guns.
- Very hard to get game Currency, weapons and things take about $30,000 to buy and per game you will get $500-$1000.
- No way to stop Spawn Camping, once your pinned inside of your spawn you are screwed.
- No Different Game Modes.



Conclusion:This game is very unbalanced and needs much more work, it is also to much of a Pay To Win game by the fact that the Premium weapons are very overpowered and can be used in any match. The matchmaking system needs some work as it will match you with anything of all skill levels and no matter what type of gun you have you will always be matched with people that have the Starter Guns and Premium Guns that are much more overpowered than all other guns in the game. The Graphics in this game suit it very well and are nicely made. This game also runs very smoothly and has a very nice cover system.



Overall Rating: 3/10

This game....no.

So, this game has some kinda interesting core mechanics that seem to focused on slower paced gameplay, working with your squads and using cover. Yes, it is a cover based multiplayer shooter, which seems kinda interesting.


Buuuuuuuuut...and thats quite a big one. There is a ton of things wrong with the game.

Monetization model! Pay ten US dollars in order to....access things such as your profile or the shop. Meaning you have to put in some money in order to buy ANYTHING. You do get level up rewards but I dont feel like this really contributes much as your extremely limited in what you have access to by default. This is also combined with the fact that, grenades. Grenades and the sort are limited use items, consumables. Which also require the ten dollar investment in order to buy more.

New player experience. Effectively, it just tells you roughly about the game and the classes and FORCIBLY(You can cancel it, though.) puts you into matchmaking. Which is mostly dead, ive waited for about an hour getting into the game. Eventually I did get a invite to a private match which is where my experience will come from. Said match had some lower level people, including me. Anyone who was new effectively got slaughtered.
To put it like this, assuming it does the full amount of damage, your starter automatic gun deals 30 damage per hit with people who have 100 health by default. This means a four shot kill assuming you are not fighting anyone with heavier armor.
Said people do infact, have armor. They also are capable of bringing around things such as a directional heat generator of sorts as a suppressor or a sort of, seemingly bulletproof shield. You do not have any of these. Only until you hit level two do you gain access to...cloak and scan. Classwise, your limited to only one class until you hit a certain level, which I believe is 6 and 12 for soldier and support respectively.
Now, remember when I said that your starter gun is a four shot kill? It is an smg. Not terribly great at range and the sort. Enemies can tote around weapons that can kill you in two shots accurately at range, another occurance happened where there was someone with an automatic shotgun that could take me out in a single shot at close ranges or kill me in about 2-3 at range.

Graphically, the game doesnt look that bad. It has this sort of sci-fi tinge to some of its enviroments. I cant really claim to have any issues here and there isnt terribly much to say about that.


Overall though. I do want to say, the game is more or less dead except for a small subset of a high experience players which causes issues for any new players as attempting to join in, your going to have to fight enemies who are just better at the game than you, has better gear that you cannot ever access without monetary investment and a population that is simply nearly nonexistant.
Is it worth downloading and playing this? I would say absolutely not.





also lil sidenote, I seemed to have issues with people shooting me through cover a few times here and there, but was not sure what the real origin of or the sort. Could be due to latency between either player, poor network handling by the games servers or simply exploits/third party software, but I cannot claim to know its exact reason.

I want to start this off by saying I've played this game for well over two years, before it was launched, and when it used to be called Ghost Recon Online.  I have a TON of gear accumulated, I have a TON of experience, and I know the game pretty thouroughly.

The recent patch (1.2.4) added in several cool features, all but one of which were requested by the community.  The features are somewhat important, but not as important as the seeming turnaround of the developers listening to the community and coding their requests.  Previously, there was (and still is) almost zero communication between the devs and the players, outside of the Community Managers/Game Masters/ATHENA Council (a team of community volunteers whose purpose is to relay community opinions and provide feedback on changes, and which I was a part of for about 9 months), but almost every change until now was not made due to community request, but rather to developer vision.  The changes were mostly made to make the game more accessible, as before, the game had a very, very high skill curve.  It still does have a high skill curve, but is now much easier to get into.

The game gives you like 150,000 AC (in-game currency) while you level up each class to level 10.  There's a queue made SOLELY for beginners. reviewText:
Alright this game is great, tight controls, excellent gunplay, plenty of room for good teamwork, medium sized playerbase, fun classes with interesting powers, and rewards player skill. I want to go back and play this game and had loads of fun with it. BUT, and this is a big stinky butt, this game is hampered by the worst F2P model possible.

They start you off with plenty of easy levels for quick in game credits and then hit the brakes hard. You have to unlock each weapon for each class sequentially and common items such as sidearms, sights, attachtments, and armor don't carry over between classes.  The tier 11 LMG is a straight upgrade in all stats to the previous tiers and they are releasing new tiers every so often. Upgraded armor is just flat better thant the previous tiers and can then be made even better by armor inserts which, by the way, are bound to the armor once used and also have their own tiers as well as pay varients that give more stat points or multiple stats per insert. Then we get into the weapons that you can no longer get and could only get by paying real money or more credits than it would have been humanly possible to earn if you like eating and sleeping such as the WAR p90 which just has a flat increase to armor penetration that the standard p90 doesn't.

Then there are the crits, every weapon has a minimum and maximum crit chance that goes up while in cover and down when moving, standard spread for sniper rifles was 1-10%. This can be further increased by using the weapon for a long time or by having a special varient such as the WAR mentioned earlier. A well loved and paid for rifle could get up to 15-40% chance to just do 3X damage because RNG.

So, now you as a free player are fighting people whose weapons do more damage, fire faster, are more stable, have more range, have a chance to one shot you, and who have more health, more armor, move faster, more crit resistance, whose abilities last longer, recharge faster, are more potent, and to top it all off look more stylin than you with their fancy skins. Then they have the nerve to release crates.

Despite all this, without spending a cent and using tier 4 or less weapons, I clawed my way up to one star general with 5 star being the max rank. There is an amazing game here that rewards tactical play and coordination but you simply reach a point where you cannot stand a chance and that's sad. The journey to 1 star was a lot of fun but became a chore near the end because I entered every fight with objectively inferior stats on all fronts. I finally gave up when I dumped a bizon mag into a recon's back and then he turned around to one shot me in the leg with the brand new money only tier 13 JGL varient sniper.

TL:DR The game is fun, there is a wonderful game under the F2P muck, don't invest too much time because the P2W model is blatent and omnipresent. ALT+QQ

reviewText:
For those that say that this game is pay to win, they are partially right. You can buy all the guns with in game currency but it takes a hell of a long time. The top tier guns ARE better. In stats and everything. eventually you will get them if you love the game.

Having said that, even the noobiest of noobs with top tier guns will still be bad at this game. This game is largely skill based. It is a true team game, no running and gunning here at the medium to top levels. All the abilities feel usefull and extremely powerful. Upgraded abilities only give a very slight advantage that is not noticable to all except the player using it. The abilities can really turn the tide of a game and they don't feel like gimmicks at all. They work to balance the playing field. The top tier guns are completely powerless in the face of the powerful abilities which you will have access to at the first levels. You get them for free when you rank your character to level 3.

I myself have reached to top ranks with a tier III weapon moded of course to be better. All the guns can be moded to suit your playstyle and needs. If you want to play a skill based game that requires teamwork and communication (mics are EXTREMELY recommended, almost mandatory for top tier play), then pick this game up. You will not be disappointed at all. However if you are a run and gun COD fan, go back to that. This game is not for you unless you have the money to drop on top tier weapons. Even then you will only get so far in this game without honing your skill.

reviewText: I have always been a fan of Ghost Recon, and Tom Clancy's games in general. This game has NOT disappointed me. As a free-to-play game, it's not exactly breaking the bank to try it out either. The gameplay is 3rd person for the most part, but when you aim down the sights of your weapon it quickly zooms you into first person. This transition is quick, smooth and very well done, and the cover-taking system and firing from cover is fluid and fast paced as well. The shooting mechanics or physics feels much more polished than a lot of other games out there. Objective-based game modes mean certain defeat if you camp in one spot for too long, or try to be a lone wolf without coordinating with your teammates. Getting to utilize some cool, perhaps-not-so-futuristic weapons technologies are the icing on the cake (optical cloaking, shoulder-mounted microwave radiation devices to literally cook your enemies, riot shields, EMP's, etc.) An emphasis on teamwork, tactics, and timing, this game is well worth a try!\n\nMy favorite of the many useful tips displayed on the loading screen If it's too quiet

Wow just wow for a free to play this game is worth at least checking out. I just started playing and this game is really fun. What makes this game so good is good stable graphics and just amazing gameplay. There really is no story if you were expecting that.

This game starts you off with three classes one for stealth one for commando and one that‚Äôs a mix. They really shove this down you and want you to really like this mechanic. The game is a hard point domination style that consists of three rounds.

You get put into a squad (that you can choose). You are your squad work together within a big team and really work on team work. You can always stay connected with you squad because they are lit up in green. Your can stay connect with your teammates because they have a blue light around them.
They game more or less uses a stealth mechanic that works about 85% of the time. If you have a good team/squad you can easily sneak up on the enemy and take them out.

The game also has a really fun slide mechanic that always you to use cover. It is really fun having slide races with your friends until you get shot in the face.

There is also a detection mechanic that lets you see the enemy if they stay in the same spot for too long so it eliminates camping.

There are still some bad things though. When you go to iron sight mode the game changes from third to first person. It‚Äôs not a giant deal unless you are using the pistol. You can‚Äôt even see your own hands. It can be really annoying sometimes.

Also the game kind of is pay to win. If your guy has the most tricked out gun that he spent $2-$10 on you are screwed. That ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•is me off when you have pay to eon games. Besides that this game is really fun with your friends and can be a good challenge and a good change of game type.

reviewText:
Usually I buy a product and never bother to write a review about it because I‚Äôm lazy but in the case of GRP/GRO I have been involved in the beta phases and I felt the need to write a review since I helped groom this baby. First of all don‚Äôt let my steam hours fool you because I probably have the most hours in this game than anyone else. I have participated in closed beta since the beginning of GRO which feels like decades ago and of course open beta too. This game very addictive, almost as addictive as chocolate or beer ÔÅä and is very different from your other fav. Shooter games. It requires a lot of teamwork, precision aiming, 200% awareness, coordinated device usage, and lots of communication. Most people will tell you it‚Äôs a camping game but don‚Äôt be fooled by that because he who camps the most is likely to lose no matter what he has in his arsenal. There are multiple play styles to fit your needs, if you are a run and gun player then just customize your weapons (modmaster) with low ready time and get the feel for it. If you are a cover system player there are a lot of weapons for each class that will fit your needs. A lot of guys will say P2W, which was the hottest topic in the beta phases and the dev teams have worked really hard to make sure everyone (cash payers‚Äô vs free players) can progress in this game decently. Now the economy is not at its best but trust me it has got a lot better in the past couple of months, weapons have been balanced so that even the lowest weapons can do decent damage so just because some kid is running around with a painted p90 doesn‚Äôt mean his the king, in GRP it‚Äôs 80% skills, 10% gear, and 10% spray and pray ÔÅä.  Now if you want to be competitive in this game and stay competitive you have to spend money or an insane amount of hour to grind for your gear, my advice is pay the 9.99 for AAA membership and get the 100% which last for 30days and gets you an insane amount of Athena Credits (in game currency). The AAA membership also gives you the chance to acquire some gear and weapon at a discount price with cash or Athena credits.

That was the pros about GRP now of course GRP isn‚Äôt even remotely close to  being the perfect game out there like any other game it has its bugs. Usually the hot topic is Match Making in all shooter games but I can‚Äôt give a negative review on that yet because in beta we had a small player pool and it sucked but now they implemented a new system of MM and it‚Äôs not going to start to take effect until the new players start leveling up and acquiring gear so I will wait on that. The other issues are, on all the maps there are cover glitches which will give advantage to one side and make you rage sometimes, there is also lag that will give you 1 or 2 grey hairs during your GRP experience, which is still the hottest topic with the dev team. My favorite bug of all is the genetically modified plants, which will blow your mind when you sniper rifle does 20 headshot damage. These are the major issues that will make you rage a lot as time goes on but GRP has a unique way of bringing out peoples rage trust me I‚Äôve seen it all.

Overall very good shooter game that is different from most shooter games out there, it‚Äôs very fun to play with friends and hear them when the game brings out their hidden inner rage and of course there is also that moment of satisfaction when you drop someone like a fly. The GM staff are fun and friendly to help you with all your problems just don‚Äôt be shy to contact them, the CMs are cool too usually they will help you out with a SOON(GRP joke) response and make sure if you have questions about the game or want to get better to visit the forums or go to peoples stream. If you want to see some youtube videos of clan matches or montage videos just visit youtube.com/ClanPhx and I stream at twitch.tv/bournelegacy too.

reviewText:
As someone that spent ample time when this, while it was Ghost Recon Online Beta, I wanted to like this game; it was everything I was looking for in a multiplayer shooter; it was tactical, relied on teamwork more than your fire-power, and it emphasised skill and strategy.

Aesthetically, the game looks great, it is a well-polished game overall and perhaps one the most polished free-to-play titles since Team Fortress 2. Animations are top-notch with near expected triple A quality visuals. Weaponry is well modelled; gun-play is satisfying and the upgrade options almost limitless.

Maps are linear, the reason why this is good is that a well-designed linear map creates a front for a team to win one; a ‚Äúwar-zone‚Äù where the team must work together and push as one, so fights are organised and aren‚Äôt death-pits such as what most generic multi-player FPS games offer.

The game starts you off in a ‚Äòbeginner‚Äô bracket; everyone from the ranks of 1 to 7 is playing together, working out the mechanics, while each on their own is improving their skills. Those first few hours might be some of the best multi-player experiences one would ever have, and probably one of the best free-to-play experiences.

But then, when your class gets to rank 8, you graduate into the ‚Äòveteran‚Äô bracket. There is no in-between and no turning back; you‚Äôre dancing with the level 30+ big-boys now who can annihilate you on their own. In with that, you‚Äôre also competing with the unskilled pay-to-winners, the equipment they can buy will make them nearly invulnerable to just about anything and the guns‚Ä¶ well, they can get ludicrously and horrendously overpowered and the snatching at your wallet becomes apparent.

Match making does not distinguish between paying and non-paying players, they say that matchmaking takes equipment and level into account, but because of how few people are playing, this doesn‚Äôt make the slightest difference. You will fight whoever is available. So because of vets who may have actually earned their equipment and the pay-to-winners that have bought everything without any development of their skills, the game dissolves from what was one of the classiest and advanced tactical cover shooters you‚Äôve ever played to a Third Person Shooter version of CoD, with impervious tanks of immature pre-teens that have all found a way of maintaining a sexual relationship with your mother. It‚Äôs truly disappointing, as this game first appeared to appeal to the real fans, but then became a game that appealed to the standard shooter demographic.

Don‚Äôt be fooled by this game claiming to be free-to-play. The play-to-win nature of this game is blatantly obvious and just flat out egregious. People may claim that you are free-to-play without paying, but this is an extremely disingenuous assertion. Not paying puts you at severe disadvantage where other players will steam roll you, and once you reach a certain level, most players would have paid. Ultimately, you will have two choices if you play this game; either, stop playing because you are out-competed, or start shelling out your cash, and I mean tons of it. Everything in this game is extremely high-priced.

reviewText:
Fight Together or Die Alone. It's not an overstatement.

Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Phantoms, previously Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Online, is a tactical third-person-shooter with an excellent formula to ensure that the experience was truly tactical. Players are divided into teams of 8, contesting the ownership of control points that determines the victory of the match. Using covers, players can advance into a safe position, or even set up a defensive position. Players are also given devices that can turn the tide of the battle; a heat-emitting device that suppresses enemies, a device that projects a spherical field that deflects bullets, a cloak, and a few more of these amazing 'toys'. All these devices, however, must be used in coordination - failure to strategize moments to attack will only cause the waste of such precious devices, but can also push the team back. Communication is key - Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Phantoms upholds it, and the in-game voice-communication system supports it.

The best things about Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Phantoms can be summarized in a few points. The first one is its cover mechanics. No game has been able to reproduce the responsiveness of the cover mechanic that Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Phantoms employ. Control feels great that it was difficult to make mistakes. Another way this game shines above the rest is that Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Phantoms makes teamwork very crucial. It was actually very difficult to go through each match solo. This kind of teamwork is something that many games had tried to produce, but failed.

However, no particular game has no flaw. Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Phantoms has 2 problems within its gameplay. First - matchmaking is SOMETIMES flawed. Sometimes teams aren't distributed equally, leaving one team obnoxiously stronger than the other. Second - it was made pretty blatant that 'a Tier VII gun is better than a Tier I gun'. This means that players who just stepped into the battlefield may face a squad of veterans with their overpowered guns. Everyone can get these weapons, but they must commit to the game or pay money to get them quickly. This, however, is a day-one observation, and as the game grows, changes might be implemented.

Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Phantoms is amazing. If you ignore all the bad things, there is no other experience that is better than Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Phantoms.

Trust me when I said it beats the living daylights out of other tactical shooters.


tl;dr?

+Great cover mechanics.
+Huge emphasis on teamwork - and it's rewarding.

-Sometimes flawed matchmaking (note that this is a day-one observation and user experience may vary).
-Blatant unbalance in equipments. Solvable through dedication or paying money.

P.S. This game is free. Give it a try before you drop it.

reviewText: The Ghost Recon franchise started all the way back with Ghost Recon (NOTHING). It was made in 2002 (i think), and focuse on long drawn out missions with intense stealthy fights and very enjoyable gameplay. The firefights were addicting, the sneaking around trying to do the objectives was addicting - it was all very addicting. Even the split screen on the OG XBOX was amazing. I spent countless hours with my sneaking down a dark corridor only to have my brother jump out of a corner, blow me to bits and scare the crap out of me. That was by far the best Ghost Recon yet. Ghost Recon 2 came along. Ghost Recon 2 Summit Strike and Ghost Recon 2 First Contact. Those were also bloody amazing. It expanded on the weapons system, had enormous maps in which you had to plan your moves carefully, and were afraid that someone was gonna come jumping out of the woods. The split screen was yet again amazing. I remember playing with my brother against to of my cousins. The enemy was hiding under a bridge right next to a small hut surrounded by a  farm. My brother and I split up. He went through the woods and I snuck through the cornfield on my belly. Pretty soon we jumped out of nowhere, flanked em and destroyed them. We all laughed - hard. Next came Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter. This is where it went awry in a way. It was still loads of fun but it left behind the stealth feel to Ghost Recon and proceded with urban close up combat. The campaign was still a blast as it was difficult but it didn't feel like the Ghost Recon I knew. The split screen was even better, offering you awesome intense 2v2 battles that would stick in your memory forever. Next came along Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter 2. I don't know much about this game except that It was much like GRAW 1. I never played GRAW 2. Next came Ghost Recon Future Soldier. This one was okay. It went back to the stealth roots of Ghost Recon during the campaign and was enjoable but didn't carry the same feel as the older ones. It was still a great game, but the multiplayer was on the sketchy side. There was a Ghost Recon for the wii but that failed. The additions to Ghost Recon 1, Jungle Storm and Island Thunder were both fun too. Now, then came along Ghost Recon: Phantoms. The thing Im here to review. Here is where everything Ghost Recon was about, was dropped. The stealth aspect is completely gone, the ony gamemodes there are is conquest and domination eg. CAPTURE THIS CAPTURE THAT. DEFEND THIS DEFEND THAT. It simply dropped the feel of the entire Ghost Recon series. Good job Ubisoft! Kudos to you. The cover system is okay, and there are a variety of weapons that you can upgrade. It was fun for the first 20 hours when everyone had the same weapons and everything was fair. If you wanted better guns, you earned them by doing well. Then after level 5, everything went ludicrous and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. You have people wielding lvl 9 guns when ur lvl 2 and armor that lets you not even tickle them. They paid easily 50 - 100 $ on all this stuff and so there's nothing I can do to get new weapons except stand up and die (which does nothing). So, the decisions is yours. Im tired of it, but if you have a friend it can be bearable. Cheers!

reviewText: I'm going to start by saying that anyone who addresses this game as another pay to win" game clearly either just aren't tactical enough or good enough. Yes
date: it's true that you can buy weapons and armor. But weapons and armor mean absolutely nothing if your teammates won't work together. This is the best tactical FPS I've ever played because it runs and FEELS like one. In fact
recommended: I question all the other 'tactical FPS' shooters after playing this one. Because most that carry that title still really feel like a run n gun shooter. In this game
hoursPlayed: teamwork truly counts. You could have a team of all elite players and another team with all level ones and the newbies could easily win. And of course vise versa.\n\nThe good: TCGRP is a very well polished game. It lets you keep track of where your teammates are on the battlefield by highlighting them and creating a sort of "dot to dot" link between you and them when close by. The game uses the third person cover system that we all know and love from games like Splinter Cell and Uncharted. When you enter cover it even tells you the bonuses for doing so and of course it makes it feel like an actual guerilla warfare battle and it's a great way to ambush your opponents. And something you'll all love to hear: PAY TO WIN DOESN'T APPLY TO THIS GAME. I've played matches with a team with all pay to win guns and armor....and lost terribly to lower levels simply because our team refused to work well together. So go ahead and waste money; but it never guarantees your victory. In fact
voteText:
it barely guarantees an advantage at all.

The bad: Lag. Every game has it and it's unavoidable. Is it the game itself? No. It is other players and has (to my knowledge with all my experience thus far) nothing to do with the servers or game at all. I've never lagged before. But I have been killed through walls after peeking out due to huge differences in connection. Could it be hacking? Of course. But I've heard no rumors or complaints about it other than the usual whiny player who rages because he isn't doing good and thinks himself a pro player.

One of the big differences to this game compared to almost all other shooters is that it's hard to avoid grenades. It's annoying of course; but realistic. Armor really weighs you down whether it's light or heavy so it should be. If the developers see this: add a somersault system. Not a lightning fast one but a realistic one like you've done with everything else. It'll add to the already really good experience. And see if you can come up with some unique gameplay modes! I highly recommend downloading and being a part of this awesome experience."

reviewText:
Well, Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Phantoms is a tactical multiplayer third person shooter from the popular franchise of Ghost Recon. What i like about this game is really the tactical aspect of it, In this game you really need your teammates to survive because you can't cover all the possible enemy advancement and you need your teammates to cover that for you, and they need you to cover their back as well. The gameplay mechanic is tactical but you just do the tactical part without the game force you to do that. Like when your teamates is behind the enemy line and you have a scanner to scan the enemy position, you just know that you need to use that to support your teammates so they didn't get killed from behind. And the game reward you with point everytime you help your teammates. Or when one of your teammates is using shield bubble to deflect bullet from him and all his teammates, you just know that you have to go with him and support his back so you both can advance to the enemy position without getting killed. Doing all of that is very fun and satisfying, knowing that you helped your teammates advance just because you use scanner to scan the enemy position is very satisfying.
But, what i kinda didn't like about this game is the fact that this game is really pay to win. There's couple of very powerful weapon like the P90 Gold that you need to pay real money to get that. But, even though it is pay to win, i'm glad to pay a couple of dollars just to experience this game. Because it is that good.
I recommend this to all people that think CS GO competitive is too serious or COD is too arcade like.

reviewText:
I dont normally write reviews, but i figured i would for this game.  Being that it is free to play, i didnt expect much more than a poorly designed game in which skill was replaced by your wallet.  After a few days now of playing i can see that was very much not the case.

In this game, i could spend money and buy everything and it would probably only make the difference of surviving one or two more shots, and maybe killing in 1-2 less shots.  While this does give a small advantage, you can still be the top player in a game  full of paying players without having paid a dime(ive been there).  Let alone with a little grinding you can purchase most everything in the game.

The game requires a little thought, and a lot of team work to be successful.  Every class has a choice of picking 1 of 2 abilities, and using those abilities at the right moment, as well as your team responding to when you use them, can quite often be the difference in a match.  Positioning is crucial, and sometimes knowing an enemies path and picking the right moment to position somewhere randomly in that path can score you 3-4 easy kills and turn the tide of a game.  This is where skill and intelligence beats out the small advantage money gives you, as i rack up a good deal of my kills off flanking and pushing up to take cover in an enemies path that they probably dont expect me to be.

For the CoD fans, there are moments where you can just rush around a corner and go off....sometimes it works, however against a smart team it more than likely wont.  For fans of games that require skill, and team work....this game is perfect.  There are even clan matches and rankings which i havent gotten in to yet, so i wont review those.

All in all i give this game a 9/10 for my interest in shooters.  The only point im taking off is the lack of diversity in game types, although i dont get bored because of that, it would be nice to have different game modes besides capturing points, such as just team deathmatch on smaller maps, or the good ole plant/defuse bomb" mode.

TLDR:  Give it a try
recommended: takes some skill and thought and is pretty addicting."

reviewText:
The game runs fine and performs like an average TPS. The damage system is fun and gives off an RPG feel a la Borderlands. The cover system is currently buggy and sometimes unintuitive. The modding of weapons is fun to use if a little sparse of choice. The class system is restrictive but brings some interesting elements with unique activatables and auras. Currently, the matchmaking takes you into a beginning queue until you have a class at Lvl 8 after which you are matched with everyone else. While in a match you cannot switch classes, sticking you with a choice of two primary weapon types and a secondary handgun, depeneding on your class.

The main problems I had with the game were with the progression system and the in-game market.

You use in-game currency to buy weapons, armor, mods, grenades, special ammo (Magnum Ammo +20% Dmg), and cosmetics. The weapons used in game are seperated into tiers 1-7. These weapons, from what I've seen, scale linearly and have to be unlocked in order. The tier 7 weapons and equipment are outright better than any previous tier, and even have an in-game metric to show it. You can either use the in-game earned currency to buy these, or buy a seperate currency to purchase them with. From what I've experienced, you are not matched seperately based on the tier of your equipment, and as such can be match against someone using a much higher tier of equipment than you. The disparity in power is great enough that it's obvious when someone has better gear.

You may get to the same gear, eventually, but paying with money is much faster and easier. But until you do, it's simple, you're stuff sucks, their stuff doesn't.

reviewText:
(Read the full review here: www.damngoodgaming.wordpress.com)

The last 30 seconds of the match are counting down fast. Me, a Support and an Assault have just cleared out all the enemies from Capture Point Charlie. I‚Äôve taken some shots on the way, leaving my hitpoints in the red. I hug cover while my teammates guard both sides, communicating enemy positions through VOIP and asking for support. The point is 90 percent capped‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs when things go south.

An enemy sniper takes out the Assault, who managed to identify the enemy‚Äôs position right before he is shot. Anticipating the enemy‚Äôs rush to retake the objective, my support pops his Active Protection System, a ‚ÄúBubble‚Äù that deflects all incoming fire. He then opens up with his light machine gun, taking down two of the flankers. The bubble shields him from bullets, but not the grenade that clunks right behind him. Soon, I‚Äôm the last one left on the point. Amidst the confusion and gunfire, the enemies fail to notice the transparent, human-like figure near them. As my Cloak energy runs out, I relay the last known position of the sniper to my newly respawned teammates before squeezing the trigger on my PP-19 submachine gun. One, two, three bursts take out three of my assailants before my screen flashes red. I die, but the enemy team is thinned out, and my team recaptures the point, swinging the balance to our favor.

Tense moments like these are the norm in Tom Clancy‚Äôs Ghost Recon: Phantoms, a free-to-play tactical action game from Ubisoft Singapore. What originally started off as Ghost Recon Online, it has been in development and beta since August 15, 2012. The game has undergone numerous updates since then, and has been released completely on Steam, April 10, 2014.


The game features three unique classes, with two interchangeable abilities and two types of weapons for each class, allowing for many different playstyles. Weapons and armor can be further customized with an assortment of attachments, and players are able to effectively turn submachine guns into medium-ranged carbines, or sniper rifles into assault weapons.You can play as a countersniper, using optical camouflage to outsmart enemy marksmen, or a bullrushing assault that prefers to use shotguns and a ballistic shield. The choice is yours.  Classes can only be chosen at the beginning, although active and passive special abilities can be swapped between each respawn. All weapons are highly lethal, and players die in a heartbeat from concentrated fire, making cover, positioning and teamwork more important than twitch reflexes. This is made more important by the fact that most maps have a linear nature to them, and it becomes difficult to assault an entrenched enemy position without proper use of skills or coordination with other classes.


However, don‚Äôt be fooled: Despite the simple linearity of the maps, there is a lot of depth to them. The maps resemble those from Counterstrike or even League of Legends, with multiple lanes to attack or defend from, different avenues of approach, and tons of cover. All maps are objective-based and most have multiple objectives, allowing both teams to simultaneously attack and defend a single point at a time. Due to the game‚Äôs cover system (a system similar to that of Rainbow Six: Vegas, Ghost Recon: Future Soldier and Splinter Cell: Blacklist), which allows players to have a small field of view from cover and shoot people that run around carelessly, it becomes necessary to know when to suppress and flank. It also takes a while for your Ghost or Phantom to aim down his weapon after sprinting. In this game, slow is smooth and smooth is fast. All this comes together in higher level matches, where it is literally a game of inches. Each team slowly pushes, suppresses and flanks, outsmarting and outmaneuvering the enemy team.


What makes the game so fun is its metagame, or how all these variables affect the balance and overall gameplay. Teamwork is everything in this game. It isn‚Äôt uncommon in higher level public matches for players to develop a gameplan at the lobby. For example: A Recon sends out a sonar pulse and detects enemies, before two Supports go in with a Bubble and use the EMP, effectively disabling nearby enemy skills. Two Assaults then suppress enemies with microwaves, preventing them from attacking, while a cloaked Recon flanks and wipes out what‚Äôs left of the enemy team. Winning teams call out enemy locations and guard each others flanks. There‚Äôs even a thin line showing if the teammate guarding your exposed side is still alive. The coordination required to win is akin to the huge teamfights found in MOBAs like League of Legends, and a balanced, well synchronized team can overcome great odds.


The game has received some criticism for its Class Progression system, where players are required to unlock each tier of weapon and armor or device before unlocking the next tier. This can be done through in-game currency or real cash. Weapon tiers are diagonal in the game, and while higher tier weapons may not perform better than a lower-tier one in a specific area, they are usually better in more areas than the lower tier weapon. However, players can augment and upgrade their lower tier weapon to match these higher tier ones, and at the end of the day, good positioning and four bullets kills an enemy better compared to three bullets from a higher tier weapon and a badly positioned player.

While I do agree that it can be a grind to amass the in-game currency, a study in the game‚Äôs forum (http://groforums.ubi.com/showthread.php?31651-Economy-Inspection-and-Presentation-for-GRP) has shown that a player can either grind 30-40 hours into the game to get what is considered one of the best weapons right now, or pay $10 for it ‚Äì a player can also purchase a lower tier weapon and fully customize it for that price. For a game that is free-to-play, I personally believe paying $10 is enough for the quality you‚Äôre receiving and that the pay system only provides flexibility for players who don‚Äôt have the time to invest in the game, and want to unlock more options or specialize in their weapons.


This tactical action game sets itself above the rest by providing its players with something different from most FPS and third-person shooters in the market through its emphasis on communication, tactics and teamwork.  Slow and tactical at times, and fast and frenetic at others, the best matches will have you communicating with your team, supporting them in their pushes, flanking with them, getting wiped out with them and even befriending them after the match ends. It has a lot of similarities with some of the best e-sports titles like League of Legends and DotA. If steered in the right direction by developers, I‚Äôd expect to see this game get huge in the competitive scene. Check it out if you haven‚Äôt already. It‚Äôs damn good and it‚Äôs free.

reviewText:
The full version of the incredible Ghost Recon Online, Phantoms is an online third-person cover shooter. It has added a few things from the beta (GRO). Most of these I haven't seen yet, but I can still say this is definitely worth your time.

The gameplay of GRP is awesome. It has a solid cover system that keeps this game from being too generic. The overall gameplay takes place in third-person, but switches to first-person when you aim which can greatly improve your accuracy. There are three different classes: Assault, Recon (my favorite), and Specialist. The Assault class is pretty much your normal soldier, Recon is more of a stealth class, and Specialist which I honestly don't know a whole lot about since I haven't really played as it. Each class has two special abilities such as the ability to turn invisible or scan the area to detect enemies, however these can only be eqipped one at a time. You can also buy gadgets like gunshot detectors. There are several weapons to use, from pistols to shotguns to sniper rifles to machine guns. They are all customizable so you can make your own unique weapon. The maps are pretty good size and offer lots of cool areas for battles.

The graphics for this game look great. Visually, Phantoms looks quite different from Online, making indoor areas darker and the default costume for your character is a dark color which is also different from GRO.

Although it is definitely not neccessary to buy things with real money in this game as it gives you a fairly good amount of in-game money, there is one thing I don't like about GRP: the fact that your character can only be customized if you pay real money. There isn't much character customization, just being able to switch uniforms, but I wouldn't mind if there were maybe three or four different uniforms to choose from without putting real money into this game. But if you don't want to spend money on character customization you'll be stuck with the default uniform.

Ghost Recon Phantoms (and Ghost Recon Online) is possibly the mot fun online game I've ever played. A good cover system and fun gameplay make this game unforgettable. If you like third-person shooters, cover shooters, or just want to have some fun online I highly reccomend Ghost Recon Phantoms. 9/10

reviewText:
The full version of the incredible Ghost Recon Online, Phantoms is an online third-person cover shooter. It has added a few things from the beta (GRO). Most of these I haven't seen yet, but I can still say this is definitely worth your time.

The gameplay of GRP is awesome. It has a solid cover system that keeps this game from being too generic. The overall gameplay takes place in third-person, but switches to first-person when you aim which can greatly improve your accuracy. There are three different classes: Assault, Recon (my favorite), and Specialist. The Assault class is pretty much your normal soldier, Recon is more of a stealth class, and Specialist which I honestly don't know a whole lot about since I haven't really played as it. Each class has two special abilities such as the ability to turn invisible or scan the area to detect enemies, however these can only be eqipped one at a time. You can also buy gadgets like gunshot detectors. There are several weapons to use, from pistols to shotguns to sniper rifles to machine guns. They are all customizable so you can make your own unique weapon. The maps are pretty good size and offer lots of cool areas for battles.

The graphics for this game look great. Visually, Phantoms looks quite different from Online, making indoor areas darker and the default costume for your character is a dark color which is also different from GRO.

Although it is definitely not neccessary to buy things with real money in this game as it gives you a fairly good amount of in-game money, there is one thing I don't like about GRP: the fact that your character can only be customized if you pay real money. There isn't much character customization, just being able to switch uniforms, but I wouldn't mind if there were maybe three or four different uniforms to choose from without putting real money into this game. But if you don't want to spend money on character customization you'll be stuck with the default uniform.

Ghost Recon Phantoms (and Ghost Recon Online) is possibly the mot fun online game I've ever played. A good cover system and fun gameplay make this game unforgettable. If you like third-person shooters, cover shooters, or just want to have some fun online I highly reccomend Ghost Recon Phantoms. 9/10

reviewText: A third-person shooter with a massive focus on strategic positioning and teamwork, Phantoms is the standard tactical shooter that we have begun to expect from games with Tom Clancy's name. The cover system is fluid and satisfying, although a bit sticky at times, and using the near-future gadgets and devices available is thrilling and empowering. My only complaints so far is that you can easily get equipment and weapons out of your skill class by paying money. This makes for an annoying situation in which you join a game with your fellow newbies, everyone equipped with standard startup gear except for one player, who has dumped so much money into the game that his armor is twice anyone else's and his health regenerates almost instantly. These player can be taken down with the right amount of teamwork and some good flanking, and they are fortunately far and few in between, but they bring down the game as a whole. Fortunately, the rest of the game is good enough to mostly excuse this.

reviewText:
Granted this isn't the most amazing game on the market, it's a relatively fun, easy and standard take on the modern warfare theme prevalent in the shooter genre. It has its slight flaws and bugs, but for a free to play game (albeit slightly suffering from microtransactions) it's definitely worth checking out, or at least worth the two hour download and ~4gb hard drive space.

In regards to the microtransactions, you also have the option to unlock all of the add-ons in the game through points acquired via gameplay. Therefore, no real money has to actually be spent and people with credit cards are not at a real advantage (hooray!). It is, however, faster to unlock things with real money... but isn't that the case with all mt based games?

Starting out in multiplayer is pretty easy. Some games, such as titles in the Battlefield franchise, are quite daunting to start out with as you are paired against multitudes of experienced players with all of the most advanced loadouts. Here you get put through bootcamp, where you're able to develop your skills, become accustomed to the maps and get a feel for the game without having to face any unfair match ups. Also, helpful unlocks come pretty quickly and the starter loadouts are pretty alright to begin with. So if you're a noob to shooters, never fear.

TL;DR Noob friendly, easy to get into, microtransactions don't negatively affect the game, and generally as fun as a Tom Clancy third person shooter can get.

reviewText:
To kick this review off, I'll start by saying that this game is actually pretty good.

Not great, but it's good. I'll go over why I say this later.

The gameplay and cover systems are very solid and I never really felt like I wasn't in control of my character during the heat of battle. Gunfire can be very deadly, so sticking to the safety of cover is an absolute must if you want to stay alive. Not all cover is safe though, and every entry point will need to be covered to prevent the enemy from pushing through and flanking your defenses. Map design is somewhat lackluster on particular maps, but most will offer interesting and different scenarios of engagement that are balanced for both sides. Tactics and strategies are a must if your team plans on winning, and coordination and timing amongst team members helps accomplish this. Gadgets, such as the ADS drone or the APS (AKA bubble shield), can be very big game changers when it comes to pushing objectives, which causes the opposite team to change up their tactics to counter these devices, either by coordinating the team or using their own tech. reviewText: if you came for a ghost recon game you may not like this game but, if you like tactical third person shooters then this game is for you. this game has a lot of micro transactions but all of it can be easily bought using the free currency earned from playing games and so far i haven't spent a penny on anything. you can however buy guns but from my experience none of the guns are a clear upgrade from the starting guns because they all have stat trade-offs but the starting weapons are good all-rounders. the only thing locked behind a paywall are all of the cosmetic items (hats, camos...). the game is very lacking in the graphics options department it only gives you the choice of low, medium, or high and you can change the resolution the game however looks pretty good. now to the gameplay, the guns handle pretty well and taking cover is vital in order for you to maintain constant accurate fire otherwise your gun will jump around sporadically encouraging players to fire in short bursts. the game also implements a cover system, hit space near an object and you'll get into cover, it works really well but since it's a third person game some people can corner camp, this is easily negated by firing a few accurate shots at them. the game has three classes assault, recon, and support, they each use their own class specific guns and abilities, the assault can whip out a sheild and charge forward knocking people down, the recon can cloak (very easily spotted if you pay attention, or scan for nearby targets, and the support can bring up a sheild that can block bullets for a short amount of time (not as overpowerd as you think, they move slowly and grenades or people can pass right through the sheild). the only real complaints i have about this game is the fact that they don't ever tell you how to use the store, which is the only way you can buy grenades, perks, or better gear causing a lot of the new players to be confused as to how people get suppressors, and other peices of gear. all-in-all this game is a good free to play third person shooter that encourages tactical team play and i highly reccomend it.

reviewText:
A great tactical shooter, well executed in its purpose.  The three classes are solid, especially working in tandem.  The maps could use more diversity, and so too could the guns--but the game is mere footsteps out of beta and therefore has some ways to go.

My gripe is with the players.  The community of people I've gamed with have been helpful and even chatty on the mics (which is somewhat unusual in these games because most gamers are not that social)--unfortunately, the developers needs money and they get yours by having you pay to win.  That's right, buy all the guns and armor you want, kids--grab that credit card like tomorrow never comes because it'll totally help you beat my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• every day.  I don't care if it helps the developers--I'd rather you ran a script and needed to kill me via a third-party program than simply forked over more cash for the gold killswhoever.  And when it's a whole team of these ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s you get the unluck of being slotted against because--and here's another ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing problem--the matchmaking doesn't take into account your equipment.  It hardly takes into account your qualifications/medals and therefore your levels in your classes.  You're going to get pitted against people a lot worse than you, and people who are NOT better than you, they are richer than you.

If you manage to enjoy it despite, good luck and good gaming.  I'm peacing out.

reviewText:
Ghost Recon Online (GRO) is a Tactical Third Person Shooter that incorporates modern weapons and real life tactics, also it adds a future devices that aide your fellow squad out during a fire fight.
The game lets you play three different classes which level individually from each other. The classes are recon, assault and support. Each class gives its own class device and support device. These devices help you and your squad if used properly. In GRO you will also notice cover is really important as well as knowing your surroundings. The game has great graphics, and surprisingly good BGM in the menus and the logging screen. Since it is an online game it lacks a story/ campaign. The controls are good, and easy to get use to if you are not use to common controls. The game also does not have cinematic which seems quite normal with online games. The gameplay is intense and gives a great rush of enjoyment and adrenaline.
When actually fighting you will notice it is quite hard to do all this and that‚Äôs what makes it fun. It makes you think and be on your toes, giving you that adrenaline rush that you surge for in a shooter. In this game you‚Äôll notice even making one mistake can kill you, for example popping out of cover to look for an enemy can easily get you killed by a Recon Sniper. This makes it feel that much more like a real fire fight, having this do or die action leaves a feeling to strive for more, and get revenge. This game also adds a great feature of sliding and having the gun being able to go around corners while in cover. This is because the gun and the camera are not together like most shooters. They are semi-separate.

The things I really liked were the Semi-separated camera and gun, and the cover system. I also really enjoy that each class has its own level making it have more gameplay overall. The things I disliked about the game is after you achieve level 5 in the class you have been playing you are no longer a beginner, and you have to face higher level characters. I also really liked how all the main things for the game like guns, attachments and devices are all sold in virtual currency earned in-game and virtual currency paid by real money. This makes it so you don‚Äôt have to pay loads of money to deck out a gun. I dislike this because since this game‚Äôs profits are made off of premium membership and in-game store, the higher levels have access to better weapons and it can seem like pay-to-win, but it is not.
Ghost Recon Online overall is a great Third-Person Shooter (TPS) and a great free online game. It has its pros and cons, like being a shooter it can be quite repetitive, but is great for playing with friends. I would even go as far as this being just as fun as some paid shooter games. In my opinion this game is scored 8/10 on gameplay, 6/10 on graphics, and a 6/10 for overall performance on an average pc.

NOTE: This game can be quite heavy on internet and pc wise. I do not recommend playing this game on slow internet or an old pc.

reviewText:
A great tactical shooter, well executed in its purpose.  The three classes are solid, especially working in tandem.  The maps could use more diversity, and so too could the guns--but the game is mere footsteps out of beta and therefore has some ways to go.

My gripe is with the players.  The community of people I've gamed with have been helpful and even chatty on the mics (which is somewhat unusual in these games because most gamers are not that social)--unfortunately, the developers needs money and they get yours by having you pay to win.  That's right, buy all the guns and armor you want, kids--grab that credit card like tomorrow never comes because it'll totally help you beat my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• every day.  I don't care if it helps the developers--I'd rather you ran a script and needed to kill me via a third-party program than simply forked over more cash for the gold killswhoever.  And when it's a whole team of these ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s you get the unluck of being slotted against because--and here's another ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing problem--the matchmaking doesn't take into account your equipment.  It hardly takes into account your qualifications/medals and therefore your levels in your classes.  You're going to get pitted against people a lot worse than you, and people who are NOT better than you, they are richer than you.

If you manage to enjoy it despite, good luck and good gaming.  I'm peacing out.

reviewText:
As I have not left the 'beginniners only' servers yet, My review may change.

I am definitely a fan of the game so far. I like the strategic elements of combat, and how balanced and different the three classes are.  A sniper for instance, will never win in a heads up close range fight. A support class will never beat a sniper at long range. Knowing what your class is capable of, the strengths and weaknesses of your load out; are essential to success in this game. More so than any shooter I have ever played. As a fan of the Soccom series, I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a similar experience.
On the flip side, Pay to win elements are all TOO obvious. The 'free' currency that is earned through combat isnt anywhere near the worth of paid currency. Honestly I would much rather astetics be the only thing one can earn through actually forking out money. But that is not the case. 20 dollars gets you the best equipment your class can offer. 20 Hours doesnt get the free player the same benefits at all. Meaning the players earn less than '1 dollar' an ingame hour. And some of the equipment is exclusive to p2p players. That being said, I fear that this game will turn into Planet Side 2. But until it does, I give it a 4.4 of 5.

Well, when I do reviews, the most logical thing to do, is nail down the pros and cons of this game.

Pros:

Great graphics.
Not pay to win
Super fun Mass effect combat style but more fluid.
And really fun when you are voice chatting with a guy you have no idea whom he is.

Cons:

Matchmaking. It is a pain to deal with and if you are anything like me, (that limits himself) you wouldn't want to sit on your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• waiting to join a match.

Overall, this game is really fun and the combat is super enjoyable. Graphics are drop dead gorgeous too. If you are a fan of Mass effect's combat, get this game ASAP.

reviewText: This is one of the best games made online in a loong time. Its a little bland with the different modes of play and could still use some improvements with gameplay, matchamaking, and the occasional little glitch. If you wanst to have the best experience playing youll need a better computer than the minimun. 2.8 dual core processor running on the lowest settign and at 14-21 FPS. Now granted it seems bad that thats the quality you get but I've been playing for 2 years at that and its defintily doable and fun at at. The business model they speak of is pretty horrible because everyone after playing puts about $30-$60+ into the game to get the latest edition of a new weapon pack and you have to grind through those palyers who jumped the gun. Its still a fun experience and you can still play quite well. A large number of the older players still use the basic starting weapons and own, so why cant you? Back to the business model, they will release or rerelease a new bundle and after a couple of months they will go and nerf the stats on the newest bundle you have in order to release another newer bundle. they dont care hwo much you have played and how much you spent. This is Ubisoft making money along with needing to repair armor after every match and pushing you to buy buy buy and giving you close to nothing after a match. Youll need to put time into this game but thats what makes it a game you dont get bored of at all. Youll want to put some 5+ hour days every now and them of pure shooting to get big jumps in coin to buy the guns.\nOverall I would definitley recommend this game to everyone! it has a couple of bugs here and there with the company but you cant beat a F2P like this

reviewText:
Uh
Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText:
Awesome game, takes a different turn in fps games as you can't just rambo rush and survive. I'd recommend playing it, i mean come on it's free what more is there to ask yourself.

As for all of the comments i've read about it being pay 2 win, thats completely false and those who say so are one of two possible people: 1, you're ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and need a scape goat excuse 2, you don't understand the game mechanics nor have you played long enough

Once you reach level 8 you get put in with the general pool of players, this includes all levels of all classes, i've versed some that are afew days into playing with nothing but the basics which you get for free that have proved to be a challenge to overcome, I have met players with hundreds of dollars worth of unique items and kits who i have walked over since i started playing.

I'm currently on the top of all of my matches earning MVP of my class, team, most headshot medal and longest killstreak medal, there has been 6 matches where I have failed to be the top player of my team, as I have played fps games for around 8 years, I consider myself an experienced player with better than good skill, and I don't care if you think i'm up myself, when you gain 80% of your class achievements in 3 days of play you deserve to boast a little.

The only downside is the amount of forgein players there are that speak other than english, it makes it hard to communicate strategies and enemy sightings.

I love this game, and if you give it a chance i'm sure you will too.

reviewText: I don't get the fuss about the whole Pay2Win deal. I've probably gotten about 60$ worth of weaponry without spending any real money. It just takes effort to actually gain enough money. And in all honesty, for my Recon character, I already got up to the M-200 without buying anything. I'm trying for the Nemesis now, but I'd strongly reccomend this game. It's tactical, gives you adrenaline rushes, and the community (While small) is quite commited for the most part. Plus the boot camp gives you easy starts before you have to deal with anyone who has top tier weaponry/armor.\nOne tip is to build each class respectively so that you can run into games and if a team is unbalanced (Say 6 recon, 2 support) you can swap to an assault and cover the gap. You don't have to buy weaponry for each class either. I'm still using the default Assault and Support weapons whilst using much higher grade weaponry for my Recon character. The point is, just be familiar with all the classes so if the team needs it, you can cover the bridge. ALSO USE A MIC, even the push-to-talk system works perfectly fine. Communication is key to success.\nSee you on the field.

reviewText:
I've spent 20$ in that  game (10$ a recon starter pack and another 10$ for a month of exp and in-game currency boosts with the AAA pass), and I am in the second highest tier already.. even if I meet some Pay 2 Win guns every game ( common example is the infamous P90 war ), I still manage to get myself in the top 5 of the game for almost every game with my lowest tier PP2000 smg ( P90 is tier V and pp2000 tier I ) still 40$ less than CoD and much more fun

Way more friendly people than flamers ( you see about 1 per 6 games, a pretty good ratio compared to CoD LoL etc ), and everyone tries to communicate and teamwork with voice comms and in game chat, even younger folks

A lot of support on the game from the devs, they do listen to people and always try to make the game as legit as possible, and I've seen people in my playing Tier that never spent a buck on the game and are in the top 8 000 players...

Of course there is some P2W aspect in the game ( looking at you, P90 and M14 Sniper ), but overall it takes way more skills than cash to win. A good squad communicating and cooperating is worth 100 P90 run 'n' gunners

Also, everything in the game beside the helmets ( aesthetic only ) can be bought with either in game money or the premium money ( gold coins )

Overall, really nice game and if you give it a try I'm sure you'll love it like I did, even if you don't spend a dime ( tho I strongly recommend a 10$ starter pack for the class you like, that's about all you'll ever need )

reviewText: As a free-to-play game, also being early access and online, this seems semi-decent at the stage it is in. This game has seemed to have taken Blacklist, taken most first-person shooters, and mixed it together. Yes, there are certain bugs, but those can be fixed as this is an early access game. It has a really nice cover system, and even if you hate cover shooters, this is acutally fun. Since it is a free-to-play, you may think there is microtransactions up the wazzoo. But there isn't, only a few here and there. There is a store, to buy weapons, but you can gain the currency by simply playing the game. Now, to the gameplay. You choose one of three classes, assault, recon, or support. This cannot be changed during the matches, or in the main menu, so choose wisely. You can play differnt gamemodes, and I cannot name them all, but expect it to be like a cod game. The graphics are decent, and as far a free-to-play goes, its pretty nice. With all of this, it's a good game, and being free to play, you should download this right away and start playing.

reviewText:
Ok, for the love of everything that is true, do NOT play this game.

At first, during it's beta days, it was definitely one of the better free-to-play games on the market. But now, it is a pay-to-play. You literally can't progress farther than level 15 unless you purchase the Infinite Pack. Don't get me wrong, the gameplay is good, but the business model has corrupted this game, and it is no longer what it was when it was in it's prime. New players literally can't find matches, and when they do, they're put up against the best players in the game because so few people play the game now. All of the best players have every single weapon in the game, and the newest weapons, specifically the AA-12 and the CBJ-MS-H Oni have ruined this game single-handedly. They are so severely over-powered, and the devs know it, but they have become so f***ng greedy that they are not fixing it, and aren't going to add what the players want. New maps, bug fixes, better servers, all of these requests are being ignored and instead they keep doing what we keep telling them not to do, add new weapons.

Onto a slightly different topic, but still to show how bad this game is. A little bit of a story...

One of the top players in the game, who was believed to be a legitimate player, was actually a hacker. He DID get banned, but shortly after, he apparantly paid Ubisoft to get unbanned and continue playing. They unbanned him, and he continued hacking, but didn't get banned. Nowadays, it's dificult to play a game without questioning the legitimacy of the people you're playing against. They pull all of the bul‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•iest maneuvers, from sliding and shooting without missing a shot, to popping out of cover and instantly killing you.

TL;DR: Game isn't what it used to be. The business model ruined it, and the servers are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Game is overall unbalanced, and literally pay-to-play. Hackers are prevalent. This game deserves to be pitied for what it once was.

reviewText: Big fan of Tom Clancy GR games. This ones different, but i am still liking it. Previous iterations of Ghost Recon saw me running around in huge open maps, needlessly blowing off the helmets of poor suckers that strayed in range of my weapon sights. Cover system over GRAW 1 and 2 multiplayer is drastically improved, but the trade off is that maps are now much more linear and a lot smaller to reflect a focus on tactics and not just who gets to the top of the hill first with guns a blazing. Hallways, lobbys and streets are the usual fare that ive noticed. Occationally you might find a back alley that doubles around and provides a nifty overlook to the poor saps that are engaged on the front lines against your team, providing you a shot at their unprotected backs. Gone is the Nowhere type maps that have you shooting targets a couple hundred yards away across open terrain. Combat is much tighter. It doesnt feel like death can come up behind you at any moment like it often does  in other games given the linear layout forcing you and your squad to team up together to advance thru choke points, but dont discount the possibility of getting shot in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. A few suprises are in store for you depending on the map and the process of learning the maps can be as simple as how the hell did he get behind me?".\nAlso: Be prepared for an uphill battle when facing off against players in the upper tiers. reviewText:
I want to put this out there: This game is NOT, I repeat, NOT, pay to win. Anything you pay for that helps your character kill the enemy or stay alive can be bought with earned in-game credits. Paying with real cash is a way to speed through the game to better things faster, but everyone has an equal chance to win. I don't pay, and I am constantly in the top 1-4 on the team.

This game is simply amazing. It is extremely user friendly, telling you how to play ingame without even watching the tutorial (which is what I did). Also, until you get to level 8 your play with BEGINNERS ONLY, which is really nice because everyone has a fair chance and there is no seal clubbing, etc.!
For the actual game play...

You choose from 3 classes: Assault, Recon, and Support.
They are all fitted to EXACTLY what the name of the class is. Assault is really good for: forward attack dishing out damage and pushing back. Recon is good for: Sniping and Flanking, you have either use a sniper rifle or an SMG. They also have the ability to cloak (go invisible) for short periods of time or scan for targets in a given area and relay the info to nearby team mates. Depends on your playstyle really. Support is not your typical run and gun down everything" player

The game, at its core, is fun. My experience with everything else has been frustrating though.

reviewText:
A super fun tactical squad-based multiplayer TPS (with classes!) that places a strong emphasis on teamwork and strategy.  Controls are smooth and the gunplay is tight. The maps are balanced and interesting, and the near-future gadgetry mixes up the combat in all the right ways.  The game's slower pacing is also quite refreshing.

It's debateable as to whether or not this game is completely P2W, but I've spent about 50 hours with this game (I've been playing this game on and off since it's initial launch as Ghost Recon Online) and I've never really felt completely underpowered or anything.  Sure, if I had dropped a few bucks here or there, I would have

Definitely would recommend this game to anyone looking for a solid TPS multiplayer game.

ALSO, the game seems to run pretty decently on low-end systems!
